required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Dialectical Behavioral Therapy Digital Health Solution for Outpatients Seeking Support for Substance Use
clinical_study.official_title: Feasibility, Acceptability, and Efficacy of a Dialectical Behavioral Therapy Digital Health Solution in the CAMH Rainbow/COMPASS Service

lead_sponsor.agency: Centre for Addiction and Mental Health

clinical_study.source: Centre for Addiction and Mental Health

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to compare the feasibility, acceptability, and efficacy of a dialectical behavior therapy skills training webapp known as "Pocket Skills" in outpatients seeking treatment for substance use, across those who receive immediate versus delayed access to the intervention (e.g., a waitlist control condition).

detailed_description.textblock: Seventy adult outpatients seeking treatment for substance use from the Centre for Addiction and Mental Health Addictions Program will be randomized to receive immediate or delayed (eight weeks) access to a web-based DBT skills training intervention called Pocket Skills in addition to standard care. Participants will complete interviews and questionnaires at week 0, at week 8, and at 2 month follow-up. Measures will assess alcohol and drug consumption, substance use disorder symptoms, and other clinical features.

primary_outcome.description: Level of dependence on most problematic substance over past 30 days. Minimum score: 0, maximum score 15. Higher scores mean worse outcome.

secondary_outcome.description: Level of depressive symptoms over the past 14 days. Minimum score: 0, maximum score 27. Higher scores mean worse outcome.
Level of generalized anxiety symptoms over the past 14 days. Minimum score: 0, maximum score 21. Higher scores mean worse outcome.

secondary_outcome.measure: Difficulties in Emotion Regulation Scale, Short Form (DERS-SF; Kaufmann et al., 2015)
secondary_outcome.description: Level of emotion dysregulation or the difficulty in changing unwanted emotions effectively in the past month. Minimum score: 18, maximum score 90. Higher scores mean worse outcome.

secondary_outcome.measure: WHO Disability Assessment Schedule Short Form (WHODAS 2.0)
secondary_outcome.description: Level of functional disability in the past month. Minimum score: 0, maximum score 48. Higher scores mean worse outcome.

Measure of core mindfulness skills around awareness and acceptance, over the past month. Minimum score: 0, maximum score 6 (mean score on 15 items). Higher scores indicate more positive outcome (e.g., more mindful awareness).

secondary_outcome.measure: Suicidal Behaviors Questionnaire, Revised (SBQ-R; Osman et al., 2001)
secondary_outcome.description: Measure of suicidal ideation and behaviors over the past month. Minimum score: 3, maximum score: 18. Higher scores indicate worse outcome.

Measure of risky and impulsive behavior, past month. Only subscales pertaining to sexual behavior and general reckless behavior will be used. Minimum score: 0, Maximum score: 40. Higher scores indicate worse outcome (e.g., more impulsive and/or risky behaviors)

Assesses the frequency of non-alcohol substance use over the past month. Minimum score per item: never used substance; maximum score per item: used substance daily or almost daily. Higher scores indicate worse outcome (e.g., more substance use).

Assesses the frequency and quantity of alcohol use and binge drinking episodes over the past month. Minimum score: no alcoholic drinks on specific day; Maximum score: 15+ drinks on a specific day. Higher scores indicate worse outcome (E.g., more alcoholic drinks consumed).

other_outcome.description: Whether or not the treatment is seen as acceptable and helpful with respect to current symptoms/problems. Minimum score: 6, maximum score: 42. Higher scores indicate better treatment acceptability and positive perceptions of the treatment.

Measure of treatment credibility and expectancy for interventions. Minimum score: 4; Maximum score: 56; Higher scores mean participants perceive the intervention to provide expected benefits and/or improvements.

arm_group.description: Pocket Skills is a dialectical behavior therapy skills training (DBT-ST) webapp that includes video lessons, an interactive chatbot AI coach, and in-app exercises to practice DBT skills. The delivery of the app will occur over eight weeks and will be supplemented with a weekly guide and links to DBT worksheets. The intervention will be delivered in conjunction with treatment as usual which includes standard psychosocial care (e.g., assessments, group, and individual programming) as part of the Addictions Program.

Waitlist control whereby outpatients will wait 8 weeks to receive the intervention and then receive the Pocket Skills webapp (subsequent 8 weeks). The waitlist period and subsequent intervention will be delivered in conjunction with treatment as usual which includes standard psychosocial care (e.g., assessments, group, and individual programming) as part of the Addictions Program.

intervention.description: Pocket Skills is a dialectical behavior therapy skills training (DBT-ST) webapp that includes video lessons, an interactive chatbot AI coach, and in-app exercises to practice DBT skills. The delivery of the app will occur over eight weeks and will be supplemented with a weekly guide and links to DBT worksheets.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. 18-65 years of age
2. Fluency in English
3. Understanding and willingness to comply with study requirements
4. Referred to Addictions Program at CAMH and on waitlist for services
5. Smartphone, tablet, or computer with access to the Internet
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Any known practical factor that would preclude participation (e.g., extended absences)
2. Untreated or unstable severe psychiatric or medical disorder that precludes participation in the study (e.g., acute suicidality, untreated psychosis)
3. Participation in another treatment/intervention study

overall_official.affiliation: Campbell Family Mental Health Research Institute, CAMH
